To understand the necessity of diodes, let's briefly examine the design of a cellphone charger. The charger transforms the line AC voltage at 110 V and 60 Hz into a DC voltage of 3.5 V. As depicted in Fig. 3.1(a), this process involves initially reducing the AC voltage using a transformer to around 4 V, followed by converting the AC voltage to DC. This same principle is applied to adapters that power various electronic devices.

How does the black box in Fig. 3.1(a) achieve this conversion? As shown in Fig. 3.1(b), the transformer's output has zero DC content because the negative and positive half cycles enclose equal areas, resulting in a zero average. Now, if this waveform is applied to a device that allows only the positive half cycles to pass while blocking the negative ones, the outcome is a waveform with a positive average and some AC components, which can be eliminated using a low-pass filter (Section 3.5.1).

image_name:(b) elimination of negative half cycles
description:The graph in Fig. 3.1(b) illustrates the process of removing negative half cycles from an AC signal in the time domain. The X-axis represents time (t), and the Y-axis represents voltage (V). The left-side waveform shows an AC signal with equal positive and negative areas, indicating zero DC content. This sinusoidal waveform has peaks at regular intervals, typical of a 60 Hz AC signal.

The right side of the graph shows the effect of a device that permits only the positive half cycles to pass, blocking the negative ones. Consequently, the waveform consists solely of positive half cycles, resulting in a signal with a positive average voltage. This transformation produces a waveform with only positive areas, effectively converting the AC signal into a pulsating DC signal.

The graph visually emphasizes the conversion process, highlighting the removal of negative half cycles, resulting in a waveform that can be further refined, such as by using a low-pass filter to smooth out remaining AC components and achieve a more stable DC output.

(b)

Figure 3.1 (a) Charger circuit, (b) elimination of negative half cycles.

Did you know?

The rectification effect was discovered by Carl Braun around 1875. He observed that a metal wire pressed against a sulphide carried more current in one direction than the other. Over the following decades, researchers explored other structures, leading to "cat's whisker" rectifiers, which were used as detectors for receiving wireless signals in early radios and radars. These were eventually replaced by pn junctions.

The waveform conversion in Fig. 3.1(b) underscores the need for a device that can distinguish between positive and negative voltages, allowing only one to pass while blocking the other. A simple resistor cannot fulfill this role because it is linear. According to Ohm's law, $V=I R$, if the voltage across a resistor shifts from positive to negative, the current through it does the same. Therefore, we need a device that acts as a short circuit for positive voltages and an open circuit for negative voltages.

Figure 3.2 encapsulates our thought process so far. The mysterious device produces an output that matches the input for positive half cycles and is zero for negative half cycles. Note that this device is nonlinear because it does not adhere to $y=\alpha x$; if $x \rightarrow-x, y \nrightarrow-y$.
image_name:Figure 3.2
description:The graph in Figure 3.2 depicts the behavior of an ideal diode in response to an input signal, shown as a time-domain waveform. The horizontal axis is labeled \( t \), representing time, while the vertical axis displays two waveforms: \( x(t) \) as the input and \( y(t) \) as the output.

The input waveform \( x(t) \) is a sinusoidal signal that oscillates above and below the horizontal axis, representing alternating positive and negative half-cycles. The output waveform \( y(t) \) is derived from \( x(t) \) and exhibits rectified behavior. For the positive half-cycles of \( x(t) \), \( y(t) \) mirrors \( x(t) \), indicating that the diode allows current to pass. For the negative half-cycles of \( x(t) \), \( y(t) \) remains at zero, showing that the diode blocks current flow.

This behavior is typical of an ideal diode, which conducts current in only one direction. The graph visually demonstrates the rectification process, where only the positive portions of the input signal are transmitted to the output, effectively clipping the negative portions. This results in a waveform that is non-linear, as it does not maintain a proportional relationship with the input.

Figure 3.2 Conceptual operation of a diode.

We analyze its response to a sinusoidal input [Figure 3.10(c)]. Since \( R_1 \) tends to keep the cathode of \( D_1 \) near zero, as \( V_{in} \) rises, \( D_1 \) is forward-biased, shorting the output to the input. This state persists for the positive half cycle. When \( V_{in} \) falls below zero, \( D_1 \) turns off, and \( R_1 \) ensures that \( V_{out} = 0 \) because \( I_D R_1 = 0 \). The circuit in Figure 3.10(b) is known as a "rectifier."

It is instructive to plot the input/output characteristic of the circuit as well. Noting that if \( V_{in} < 0 \), \( D_1 \) is off and \( V_{out} = 0 \), and if \( V_{in} > 0 \), \( D_1 \) is on and \( V_{out} = V_{in} \), we obtain the behavior shown in Figure 3.10(d). The rectifier is a nonlinear circuit because if \( V_{in} \rightarrow -V_{in} \), then \( V_{out} \nrightarrow -V_{out} \).

We now determine the time average (dc value) of the output waveform in Figure 3.10(c) to arrive at another interesting application. Suppose \( V_{in} = V_p \sin \omega t \), where \( \omega = 2 \pi / T \) denotes the frequency in radians per second and \( T \) the period. Then, in the first cycle after \( t = 0 \), we have

$$
V_{out} = V_p \sin \omega t \text { for } 0 \leq t \leq \frac{T}{2} \tag{3.3}
$$

$$
V_{out} = 0 \quad \text { for } \frac{T}{2} \leq t \leq T \tag{3.4}
$$

To compute the average, we obtain the area under \( V_{out} \) and normalize the result to the period:

$$
V_{out, avg} = \frac{1}{T} \int_{0}^{T} V_{out}(t) dt \tag{3.5}
$$

$$
V_{out, avg} = \frac{1}{T} \int_{0}^{T / 2} V_p \sin \omega t dt \tag{3.6}
$$

$$
V_{out, avg} = \frac{1}{T} \cdot \frac{V_p}{\omega}[-\cos \omega t]_{0}^{T / 2} \tag{3.7}
$$

$$
V_{out, avg} = \frac{V_p}{\pi} \tag{3.8}
$$

Thus, the average is proportional to \( V_p \), an expected result because a larger input amplitude yields a greater area under the rectified half cycles.

This observation reveals that the average value of a rectified output can serve as a measure of the "strength" (amplitude) of the input. That is, a rectifier can operate as a "signal strength indicator." For example, since cellphones receive varying levels of signal depending on the user's location and environment, they require an indicator to determine how much the signal must be amplified.

Example: A cellphone receives a 1.8-GHz signal with a peak amplitude ranging from 2 μV to 3.9 mV. If the signal is applied to a rectifier, what is the corresponding range of the output average?

The rectified output exhibits an average value ranging from \( 2 \mu V /(\pi) = 0.637 \mu V \) to \( 10 mV /(\pi) = 3.18 mV \).

In our effort toward understanding the role of diodes, we examine another circuit that will eventually lead to some important applications. First, consider the topology in Figure 3.11(a), where a 1-V battery is placed in series with an ideal diode. How does this circuit behave? If \( V_1 < 0 \), the cathode voltage is higher than the anode voltage, placing \( D_1 \) in reverse bias. Even if \( V_1 \) is slightly greater than zero, e.g., equal to 0.9 V, the anode is not positive enough to forward bias \( D_1 \). Thus, \( V_1 \) must approach +1 V for \( D_1 \) to turn on. Shown in Figure 3.11(a), the I/V characteristic of the diode-battery combination resembles that of a diode, but shifted to the right by 1 V.

Now, let us examine the circuit in Figure 3.11(b). Here, for \( V_{in} < 0 \), \( D_1 \) remains off, yielding \( V_{out} = V_{in} \). For \( V_{in} > 0 \), \( D_1 \) acts as a short, and \( V_{out} = 0 \). The circuit therefore does not allow the output to exceed zero, as illustrated in the output waveform and the input/output characteristic. But suppose we seek a circuit that must not allow the output to exceed +1 V (rather than zero). How should the circuit of Figure 3.11(b) be modified? In this case, \( D_1 \) must turn on only when \( V_{out} \) approaches +1 V, implying that a 1-V battery must be inserted in series with the diode. Depicted in Figure 3.11(c), the modification indeed guarantees \( V_{out} \leq +1 V \) for any input level. We say the circuit "clips" or "limits" at +1 V. "Limiters" prove useful in many applications and are described in Section 3.5.3.

Sketch the time average of \( V_{out} \) in Figure 3.11(c) for a sinusoidal input as the battery voltage, \( V_B \), varies from \( -\infty \) to \( +\infty \).

If \( V_B \) is very negative, \( D_1 \) is always on because \( V_{in} \geq -V_p \). In this case, the output average is equal to \( V_B \) [Figure 3.12(a)]. For \( -V_p < V_B < 0 \), \( D_1 \) turns off at some point in the negative half cycle and remains off in the positive half cycle, yielding an average greater than \( -V_p \) but less than \( V_B \). For \( V_B = 0 \), the average reaches \( -V_p /(\pi) \). Finally, for \( V_B \geq V_p \), no limiting occurs, and the average is equal to zero. Figure 3.12(b) sketches this behavior.

We now determine the time average (dc value) of the output waveform in Fig. 3.10(c) to arrive at another interesting application. Suppose \( V_{in} = V_p \sin \omega t \), where \( \omega = 2 \pi / T \) denotes the frequency in radians per second and \( T \) the period. Then, in the first cycle after \( t = 0 \), we have

$$
\begin{align*}
V_{out} & = V_p \sin \omega t \text { for } 0 \leq t \leq \frac{T}{2} \tag{3.3}\\
& = 0 \quad \text { for } \frac{T}{2} \leq t \leq T \tag{3.4}
\end{align*}
$$

To compute the average, we obtain the area under \( V_{out} \) and normalize the result to the period:

$$
\begin{align*}
V_{out, avg} & = \frac{1}{T} \int_{0}^{T} V_{out}(t) dt \tag{3.5}\\
& = \frac{1}{T} \int_{0}^{T / 2} V_p \sin \omega t dt \tag{3.6}\\
& = \frac{1}{T} \cdot \frac{V_p}{\omega}[-\cos \omega t]_{0}^{T / 2} \tag{3.7}\\
& = \frac{V_p}{\pi} \tag{3.8}
\end{align*}
$$

Thus, the average is proportional to \( V_p \), an expected result because a larger input amplitude yields a greater area under the rectified half cycles.

The above observation reveals that the average value of a rectified output can serve as a measure of the "strength" (amplitude) of the input. For example, since cellphones receive varying levels of signal depending on the user's location and environment, they require an indicator to determine how much the signal must be amplified.

\[ V_{\text{out, avg}} = \frac{1}{T} \int_0^{T/2} V_p \sin \omega t dt \]
\[ V_{\text{out, avg}} = \frac{1}{T} \cdot \frac{V_p}{\omega}[-\cos \omega t]_0^{T/2} \]
\[ V_{\text{out, avg}} = \frac{V_p}{\pi} \]

Thus, the average is proportional to \( V_p \), which is an expected result since a larger input amplitude results in a greater area under the rectified half cycles.

This observation indicates that the average value of a rectified output can serve as an indicator of the "strength" (amplitude) of the input. In other words, a rectifier can function as a "signal strength indicator." For instance, since cellphones receive varying signal levels depending on the user's location and environment, they require an indicator to determine the necessary amplification level of the signal.

Example: A cellphone receives a 1.8-GHz signal with a peak amplitude ranging from 2 μV to 3.9 mV. If this signal is applied to a rectifier, what is the corresponding range of the output average?

Solution: The rectified output exhibits an average value ranging from \( \frac{2 \mu V}{\pi} = 0.637 \mu V \) to \( \frac{10 mV}{\pi} = 3.18 mV \).

Referring to Figure 3.15, diodes $D_1$ and $D_2$ exhibit distinct cross-sectional areas while sharing identical properties otherwise. The task is to ascertain the current traversing each diode.

Figure 3.15 depicts a diode circuit with the following components:
- Voltage source $V1$ connected to resistor $R1$, forming a series connection.
- Diodes $D1$ and $D2$ are connected in parallel, with their anodes linked to node $X1$ and their cathodes grounded.

For this scenario, the application of the exponential equation is mandatory as the ideal and constant-voltage models do not account for the device area. The total incoming current $I_{in}$ is the sum of the currents through $D_1$ and $D_2$:

$$
I_{in} = I_{D1} + I_{D2}
$$

Moreover, the voltage across $D_1$ and $D_2$ is equated:

$$
V_T \ln \frac{I_{D1}}{I_{S1}} = V_T \ln \frac{I_{D2}}{I_{S2}}
$$

This simplifies to:

$$
\frac{I_{D1}}{I_{S1}} = \frac{I_{D2}}{I_{S2}}
$$

Concurrently solving equations (3.13) and (3.15) yields:

$$
I_{D1} = \frac{I_{in}}{1 + \frac{I_{S2}}{I_{S1}}}
$$
$$
I_{D2} = \frac{I_{in}}{1 + \frac{I_{S1}}{I_{S2}}}
$$

When $I_{S1} = I_{S2}$, as anticipated, $I_{D1} = I_{D2} = \frac{I_{in}}{2}$.

This graph is a characteristic curve, typically employed in electronics to depict how output voltage varies with input voltage in a specific circuit setup. The initial linear region exhibits a linear increase in $V_{out}$ with $V_{in}$, adhering to the slope dictated by the ratio $\frac{R_2}{R_1 + R_2}$, indicating the diode $D_1$ is off, and the circuit behaves as a simple voltage divider. The threshold point is marked by $V_{in}$ equalling $(1 + \frac{R_1}{R_2})V_{D,\text{on}}$, signaling the activation of diode $D_1$. In the circuit depicted in Figure 3.16, when $V_{\text{in}} = -\infty$, $D_1$ is reverse-biased, simplifying the circuit to Figure 3.16(b). Hence,

$$
v_{\text{out}} = \frac{R_2}{R_1 + R_2} V_{in}
$$

To determine when $D_1$ turns on, the diode voltage must reach $V_{D,\text{on}}$, requiring an input voltage given by:

$$
\frac{R_2}{R_1 + R_2} V_{in} = V_{D,\text{on}}
$$

Thus,

$$
V_{in} = \left(1 + \frac{R_1}{R_2}\right) V_{D,\text{on}}
$$

Readers may question the validity of this result: if the diode is on, it conducts current, and the diode voltage is no longer equal to $\left[R_2 / \left(R_1 + R_2\right)\right] V_{in}$. The reasoning behind expressing the diode voltage as such in Eq. (3.18) is to determine the break point by assuming $V_{\text{in}}$ gradually increases, placing the diode at the brink of turning on.

For $V_{\text{in}} > \left(1 + \frac{R_1}{R_2}\right) V_{D,\text{on}}$, $D_1$ remains forward-biased, resulting in $V_{\text{out}} = V_{D,\text{on}}$. Figure 3.16(c) plots the overall characteristic.

The circuit consists of a diode $D1$, two resistors $R1$ and $R2$, and a voltage source $Vin$. The diode becomes forward-biased when $Vin$ exceeds the diode's threshold voltage, allowing current flow through $R2$ and $D1$. $R1$ connects node $X$ to ground, influencing the output voltage $Vout$ at node $X$.

For very negative $V_{\text{in}}$, the circuit is redrawn as in Figure 3.17(b), positioning the more negative voltages at the bottom and the more positive voltages at the top. Note that in this regime, $V_X$ is independent of $R_2$ as $D_1$ acts as a voltage source. Thus, as long as $D_1$ is on, we have:

$$
V_{\text{out}} = V_{\text{in}} + V_{D,\text{on}}
$$

The currents through $R_2$ and $R_1$ are computed:

$$
I_{R2} = \frac{V_{D,\text{on}}}{R_2}
$$
$$

Determining when $D_1$ turns off is simpler by seeking the condition that yields zero current through the diode rather than insufficient voltage across it. $$
\frac{V_{D,\text{on}}}{R_2} = -\frac{V_{in} + V_{D,\text{on}}}{R_1}
$$

Hence,

$$
V_{in} = -\left(1 + \frac{R_1}{R_2}\right) V_{D,\text{on}}
$$

Beyond this value, the circuit simplifies to that shown in Figure 3.17(c), and

$$
V_{\text{out}} = \frac{R_1}{R_1 + R_2} V_{\text{in}}
$$

As mentioned in Example 3.4, in more complex circuits, predicting the region of operation for each diode by inspection can be challenging. In such cases, one may make an educated guess, proceed with the analysis, and later verify if the results align with the initial assumption. The following example demonstrates this approach.

Plot the input/output characteristic of the circuit shown in Figure 3.18(a) using the constant-voltage diode model.

Starting with $V_{\text{in}} = -\infty$, an intuitive prediction is made that $D_1$ is on. A blind assumption is made that $D_2$ is also on, simplifying the circuit to that in Figure 3.18(b). The path through $V_{D,\text{on}}$ and $V_B$ creates a voltage difference of $V_{D,\text{on}} + V_B$ between $V_{\text{in}}$ and $V_{\text{out}}$, i.e., $V_{\text{out}} = V_{\text{in}} - (V_{D,\text{on}} + V_B)$. This voltage difference also appears across the branch consisting of $R_1$ and $V_{D,\text{on}}$, resulting in:

$$
R_1 I_{R1} + V_{D,\text{on}} = -(V_B + V_{D,\text{on}})
$$

Hence,

$$
I_{R1} = \frac{-V_B - 2 V_{D,\text{on}}}{R_1}
$$

$I_{R1}$ is independent of $V_{\text{in}}$. The results must now be analyzed to confirm whether they align with the assumptions regarding the states of $D_1$ and $D_2$.

Considering the current through $R_2$:

$$
I_{R2} = -\frac{V_{\text{out}}}{R_2} = -\frac{V_{\text{in}} - (V_{D,\text{on}} - V_B)}{R_2}
$$

As $V_{\text{in}}$ approaches $-\infty$, $I_{R2}$ approaches $+\infty$. The high value of $I_{R2}$ and the constant value of $I_{R1}$ indicate that the branch consisting of $V_B$ and $D_2$ carries a large current in the direction shown. This means $D_2$ must conduct current from its cathode to its anode, which is not feasible.

Thus, the forward bias assumption for $D_2$ leads to a current flowing in an impractical direction. Therefore, $D_2$ operates in reverse bias for $V_{\text{in}} = -\infty$. Redrawing the circuit as in Figure 3.18(c) and noting that $V_X = V_{\text{in}} + V_{D,\text{on}}$, we have:

$$
V_{\text{out}} = (V_{\text{in}} + V_{D,\text{on}}) \frac{R_2}{R_1 + R_2}
$$

As $V_{\text{in}}$ increases, the first break point, where $D_1$ turns off or $D_2$ turns on, is determined. Assuming $D_1$ turns off first, the corresponding $V_{\text{in}}$ value is found. With $D_2$ assumed off, the circuit is redrawn as shown in Figure 3.18(d). Recognizing that $D_1$ is slightly on, at $V_{\text{in}} \approx -V_{D,\text{on}}$, $V_X = V_{\text{in}} + V_{D,\text{on}}$ approaches zero, resulting in zero current through $R_1$, $R_2$, and hence $D_1$. The diode therefore turns off at $V_{\text{in}} = -V_{D,\text{on}}$.

The assumption that $D_2$ remains off must now be verified. At this break point, $V_X = V_{\text{out}} = 0$, making the voltage at node $Y$ equal to $+V_B$ while the cathode of $D_2$ is at $-V_{D,\text{on}}$ [Figure 3.18(e)]. Thus, $D_2$ is indeed off. Figure 3.18(f) plots the input/output characteristic computed thus far, revealing that $V_{\text{out}} = 0$ after the first break point due to zero current through $R_1$ and $R_2$.

Determining when $D_2$ turns on requires the input voltage to exceed $V_Y$ by $V_{D,\text{on}}$. Before $D_2$ turns on, $V_{\text{out}} = 0$ and $V_Y = V_B$; hence, $V_{\text{in}}$ must reach $V_B + V_{D,\text{on}}$, after which the circuit is configured as shown in Figure 3.18(g). Consequently,

$$
V_{\text{out}} = V_{\text{in}} - V_{D,\text{on}} - V_B
$$

Figure 3.18(h) plots the overall result, summarizing the regions of operation.

An exercise involves assuming $D_2$ turns on before $D_1$ turns off and demonstrating that the results conflict with the initial assumption.

The circuit in Fig. 3.15 includes a voltage source V1 connected in series with a resistor R1, which leads to a node X1. At node X1, the resistor is connected in parallel to two diodes, D1 and D2, whose anodes are connected to X1 and whose cathodes are grounded.

To address the problem at hand, we must use the exponential equation, as the ideal and constant-voltage models do not account for the diode's area. The total incoming current, $I_{in}$, is the sum of the currents through $D_{1}$ and $D_{2}$:

$$
I_{in} = I_{D1} + I_{D2} \tag{3.12}
$$

The voltage across each diode is the same, leading to the equation:

$$
V_{T} \ln \frac{I_{D1}}{I_{S1}} = V_{T} \ln \frac{I_{D2}}{I_{S2}} \tag{3.13}
$$

Which simplifies to:

$$
\frac{I_{D1}}{I_{S1}} = \frac{I_{D2}}{I_{S2}} \tag{3.14}
$$

Solving equations (3.13) and (3.15) simultaneously gives us:

$$
\begin{align*}
I_{D1} &= \frac{I_{in}}{1+\frac{I_{S2}}{I_{S1}}} \tag{3.15} \\
I_{D2} &= \frac{I_{in}}{1+\frac{I_{S1}}{I_{S2}}} \tag{3.16}
\end{align*}
$$

As anticipated, if $I_{S1} = I_{S2}$, then $I_{D1} = I_{D2} = \frac{I_{in}}{2}$.

In this scenario, the voltage across the diode equals the output voltage. We observe that if $V_{in} = -\infty$, $D_{1}$ is reverse-biased, and the circuit simplifies to that in Fig. 3.16(b). Therefore:

$$

$$

To determine when $D_{1}$ turns on, the diode voltage must reach $V_{D,on}$, requiring an input voltage given by:

$$
\frac{R_{2}}{R_{1}+R_{2}} V_{in} = V_{D,on} \tag{3.18}
$$

Hence:

$$
V_{in} = \left(1+\frac{R_{1}}{R_{2}}\right) V_{D,on} \tag{3.19}
$$

The reader may question the validity of this result: if the diode is indeed on, it draws current, and the diode voltage is no longer equal to $\left[\frac{R_{2}}{R_{1}+R_{2}}\right] V_{in}$. The reason for expressing the diode voltage as such in Eq. (3.18) is to determine the break point by assuming $V_{in}$ gradually increases to place the diode at the turn-on edge.

For $V_{in} > \left(1+\frac{R_{1}}{R_{2}}\right) V_{D,on}$, $D_{1}$ remains forward-biased, resulting in $V_{out} = V_{D,on}$. Figure 3.16(c) illustrates the overall characteristic.

Our handling of diodes to date has involved accommodating significant voltage and current fluctuations, necessitating a comprehensive model like the exponential I/V relationship. We refer to this mode as "large-signal operation" and the exponential characteristic as the "large-signal model," highlighting the model's capacity to handle varying signal intensities. Nonetheless, as previous examples have shown, this model often complicates analysis, making it hard to grasp the circuit's functionality intuitively. Moreover, as the number of nonlinear devices in a circuit grows, manual analysis eventually becomes unfeasible.

Ignore the current drawn by the cellphone. ${ }^{6}$ (a) Calculate the reverse saturation current, $I_{S 1}$ for $V_{\text {out }}=2.4 \mathrm{~V}$. (b) Compute $V_{\text {out }}$ if the adaptor voltage is actually 3.1 V.

The circuit in Fig. 3.19 includes a voltage source (Vad = 3V), a current source (Ix), a resistor (R1 = 100Ω), and three diodes (D1, D2, D3) in series. The diodes are forward-biased, and the total output voltage (Vout) is approximately 2.4V. The resistor R1 maintains the remaining 600mV. The circuit is used to power a cellphone, with the current through the diodes equal to the current through the resistor.

Solution
(a) With $V_{\text {out }}=2.4 \mathrm{~V}$, the current flowing through $R_{1}$ is

$$
\begin{align*}
I_{X} & =\frac{V_{\text {ad }}-V_{\text {out }}}{R_{1}}  \tag{3.33}\\
& =6 \mathrm{~mA} . \tag{3.34}
\end{align*}
$$

Each diode carries $I_{X}$, hence

$$
\begin{equation*}
I_{X}=I_{S} \exp \frac{V_{D}}{V_{T}} \tag{3.35}
\end{equation*}
$$

It follows that

$$
\begin{equation*}
6 \mathrm{~mA}=I_{S} \exp \frac{800 \mathrm{mV}}{26 \mathrm{mV}} \tag{3.36}
\end{equation*}
$$

and

$$
\begin{equation*}
I_{S}=2.602 \times 10^{-16} \mathrm{~A} \tag{3.37}
\end{equation*}
$$

(b) If $V_{\text {ad }}$ rises to 3.1 V, we anticipate a slight increase in $V_{\text {out }}$. To understand why, first assume $V_{\text {out }}$ remains constant at 2.4 V. Then, the additional 0.1 V must drop across $R_{1}$, increasing $I_{X}$ to 7 mA. Since the voltage across each diode has a logarithmic dependence on the current, the change from 6 mA to 7 mA indeed yields a small change in $V_{\text {out }}{ }^{7}$

To analyze the circuit quantitatively, we start with $I_{X}=7 \mathrm{~mA}$ and iterate:

$$
\begin{align*}
V_{\text {out }} & =3 V_{D}  \tag{3.38}\\
& =3 V_{T} \ln \frac{I_{X}}{I_{S}}  \tag{3.39}\\
& =2.412 \mathrm{~V} \tag{3.40}
\end{align*}
$$

This value of $V_{\text {out }}$ gives a new value for $I_{X}$:

$$
\begin{align*}
I_{X} & =\frac{V_{\text {ad }}-V_{\text {out }}}{R_{1}}  \tag{3.41}\\
& =6.88 \mathrm{~mA} \tag{3.42}
\end{align*}
$$

which translates to a new $V_{\text {out }}$:

$$
\begin{align*}
V_{\text {out }} & =3 V_{D}  \tag{3.43}\\
& =2.411 \mathrm{~V} . \tag{3.44}
\end{align*}
$$

Noting the very small difference between (3.40) and (3.44), we conclude that $V_{\text {out }}=2.411 \mathrm{~V}$ with good accuracy. The constant-voltage diode model would not be useful in this case.

The scenario described above exemplifies small "perturbations" in circuits. The change in $V_{a d}$ from 3 V to 3.1 V results in minor alterations in the circuit's voltages and currents, prompting us to seek a simpler analysis method that can replace the nonlinear equations and the inevitable iterative process. Of course, since the above example does not present an overwhelmingly difficult problem, the reader may question the necessity of a simpler approach. However, as seen in subsequent chapters, circuits containing complex devices such as transistors may indeed become impossible to analyze if the nonlinear equations are retained.

These considerations lead us to the crucial concept of "small-signal operation," where the circuit undergoes only minor changes in voltages and currents, allowing simplification through the use of "small-signal models" for nonlinear devices. The simplicity arises because such models are linear, enabling standard circuit analysis and eliminating the need for iteration. The definition of "small" will become clear later.

$$

A sinusoidal signal with a peak amplitude of \( V_p \) and a DC offset of \( V_0 \) is represented by \( V(t) = V_0 + V_p \cos(\omega t) \). When this signal is applied across a diode and \( V_p \) is much smaller than the thermal voltage \( V_T \), the resulting diode current is to be determined.

Since $V_{\text {out }}=V_{p}-V_{D, \text { on }}$ at $t=t_{1}$, the discharge of $C_{1}$ through $R_{L}$ can be expressed as:

$$
\begin{equation*}
V_{\text {out }}(t)=\left(V_{p}-V_{D, \text { on }}\right) \exp \frac{-t}{R_{L} C_{1}} \quad 0 \leq t \leq t_{3} \tag{3.75}
\end{equation*}
$$

where we have chosen $t_{1}=0$ for simplicity. To ensure a small ripple, $R_{L} C_{1}$ must be much greater than $t_{3}-t_{1}$; thus, noting that $\exp (-\epsilon) \approx 1-\epsilon$ for $\epsilon \ll 1$,

$$
\begin{align*}
V_{\text {out }}(t) \approx & \left(V_{p}-V_{D, \text { on }}\right)\left(1-\frac{t}{R_{L} C_{1}}\right)  \tag{3.76}\\
& \approx\left(V_{p}-V_{D, \text { on }}\right)-\frac{V_{p}-V_{D, \text { on }}}{R_{L}} \cdot \frac{t}{C_{1}} \tag{3.77}
\end{align*}
$$

The peak-to-peak amplitude of the ripple is equal to the amount of discharge at $t=t_{3}$. Since $t_{4}-t_{3}$ is equal to the input period, $T_{i n}$, we write $t_{3}-t_{1}=T_{\text {in }}-\Delta T$, where $\Delta T\left(=t_{4}-t_{3}\right)$ denotes the time during which $D_{1}$ is on. Thus,

$$
\begin{equation*}
V_{R}=\frac{V_{p}-V_{D . m}}{R_{L}} \frac{T_{n-n}-\Delta T}{C_{1}} \tag{3.78}
\end{equation*}
$$

Recognizing that if $C_{1}$ discharges by a small amount, then the diode turns on for only a brief period, we can assume $\Delta T \ll T_{i n}$ and hence

$$
\begin{align*}
V_{R} & \approx \frac{V_{p}-V_{D . m}}{R_{L}} \cdot \frac{T_{i}}{C_{1}}  \tag{3.79}\\
& \approx \frac{V_{p}-V_{D, \text { em }}}{R_{L} C_{1} f_{m}} \tag{3.80}
\end{align*}
$$

where $f_{\text {in }}=T_{\text {in }}^{-1}$.

To ensure the output voltage of the rectifier remains stable, it is essential to select an appropriate smoothing capacitor. The size of the capacitor influences the output ripple, which is the fluctuation in voltage that occurs due to the charging and discharging of the capacitor. The ripple voltage is a critical factor because it affects the performance of electronic devices connected to the rectifier's output.

For a full-wave rectifier, the ripple voltage can be approximated by the formula:

$$
V_{R} = \frac{I_{L}}{2 C_{1} f_{i n}}
$$

Here, \(I_{L}\) is the load current, \(C_{1}\) is the capacit capacitor, and \(f_{i n}\) is the frequency of the input voltage. To minimize the ripple, the value of \(C_{1}\) must be sufficiently large.

In the given example, we aim to design a full-wave rectifier that delivers 2 W of average power to a cellphone with a voltage of 3.6 V and a ripple of 0.2 V. First, we calculate the required peak input voltage:

$$
V_{i n, p} = 3.6 \mathrm{~V} + 2 V_{D, o n} \approx 5.2 \mathrm{~V}
$$

This ensures that the output voltage, after accounting for the diode's forward voltage drop (\(V_{D, o n}\)), is sufficient to power the cellphone.

Next, we determine the minimum value of the smoothing capacitor needed to maintain the ripple below 0.2 V. Using the formula for the ripple voltage, we can rearrange it to solve for \(C_{1}\):

$$
C_{1} = \frac{I_{L}}{2 V_{R} f_{i n}}
$$

Given \(I_{L} = \frac{2 \mathrm{~W}}{3.6 \mathrm{~V}}\) and \(f_{i n} = 60 \mathrm{~Hz}\), we find:

$$
C_{1} = 23,000 \mu \mathrm{~F}
$$

This indicates that a rather large capacitor is necessary to achieve the desired low ripple. However, in practical applications, size and cost constraints may limit the capacitor size, necessitating a trade-off between ripple amplitude and capacitor size.

The diodes in the full-wave rectifier must also be able to withstand a reverse bias voltage equal to the peak input voltage, which in this case is approximately 5.2 V.

For the exercise, if the smoothing capacitor's value is limited to \(1000 \mu \mathrm{~F}\), we would need to calculate the maximum allowable power drain to maintain the ripple below an acceptable level. This would involve solving the ripple voltage formula for \(I_{L}\) and ensuring the power delivered to the load does not exceed the calculated current.

Lastly, for very small amplitude signals, such as a 10 mV peak swing in a radio frequency signal, traditional rectifiers may not be suitable due to the diode's inability to effectively switch at such low voltages. In such cases, precision rectification techniques are employed, which are discussed in later chapters. Adding a constant voltage of 0.8 V to the signal could potentially offset the issue by ensuring the diode operates within its forward voltage range, allowing the rectification to occur.

A limiting circuit should pass the input to the output unchanged for small input levels, such as \( V_{\text {out }}=V_{\text {in }} \), and the output should remain constant when the input exceeds a "threshold" or "limit." This behavior must apply to both positive and negative inputs, corresponding to the input/output characteristic shown in Fig. 3.48(a). As shown in Fig. 3.48(b), a signal applied to the input will emerge at the output with its peak values "clipped" at \( \pm V_{L} \).

We now construct a circuit that exhibits the above behavior. The nonlinear input/output characteristic suggests that one or more diodes must turn on or off as \( V_{i n} \) approaches \( \pm V_{L} \). In fact, we have already seen simple examples in Figs. 3.11(b) and (c), where the positive half cycles of the input are clipped at 0 V and +1 V, respectively. We reexamine the former assuming a more realistic diode, such as the constant-voltage model. As shown in Fig. 3.49(a), \( V_{\text {out }} \) is equal to \( V_{\text {in }} \) for \( V_{\text {in }}<V_{D, \text { on }} \) and equal to \( V_{D, \text { on }} \) thereafter.

To serve as a more general limiting circuit, the above topology must meet two other conditions. First, the limiting level, \( V_{L} \), must be an arbitrary voltage and not necessarily equal to \( V_{D, o n} \). Inspired by the circuit of Fig. 3.11 (c), we propose that a constant voltage source in series with \( D_{1} \) shifts the limiting point, achieving this objective. As depicted in Fig. 3.49(b), the resulting circuit limits at \( V_{L}=V_{B 1}+V_{D, \text { on }} \). Note that \( V_{B 1} \) can be positive or negative to shift \( V_{L} \) to higher or lower values, respectively.

Second, the negative values of \( V_{i n} \) must also experience limiting. Starting with the circuit of Fig. 3.49(a), we recognize that if the anode and cathode of \( D_{1} \) are swapped, then the circuit limits at \( V_{i n}=-V_{D, \text { on }} \) [Fig. 3.50(a)]. Thus, as shown in Fig. 3.50(b), two "antiparallel" diodes can create a characteristic that limits at \( \pm V_{D, o n} \). Finally, inserting constant voltage sources in series with the diodes shifts the limiting points to arbitrary levels (Fig. 3.51).

The behavior of a limiting circuit should be as follows: For low input levels, the circuit should allow the input to pass through to the output unchanged, e.g., \( V_{\text {out }}=V_{\text {in }} \), and as the input level surpasses a "threshold" or "limit," the output should remain constant. This behavior should apply to both positive and negative inputs, aligning with the input/output characteristic shown in Fig. 3.48(a). As depicted in Fig. 3.48(b), a signal applied to the input emerges at the output with its peak values "clipped" at \( \pm V_{L} \).

To implement a circuit that exhibits this behavior, we must consider the nonlinear input/output characteristic, which implies that one or more diodes must activate or deactivate as \( V_{i n} \) approaches \( \pm V_{L} \). In fact, we've already encountered simple examples in Figs. 3.11(b) and (c), where the positive half cycles of the input are clipped at 0 V and +1 V, respectively. We revisit the former using a more realistic diode model, e.g., the constant-voltage model. As shown in Fig. 3.49(a), \( V_{\text {out }} \) equals \( V_{\text {in }} \) for \( V_{\text {in }}<V_{D, \text { on }} \) and equals \( V_{D, \text { on }} \) thereafter.

To serve as a more versatile limiting circuit, the aforementioned topology must fulfill two additional conditions. First, the limiting level, \( V_{L} \), must be an arbitrary voltage and not necessarily equivalent to \( V_{D, o n} \). Drawing inspiration from the circuit in Fig. 3.11 (c), we propose that a constant voltage source in series with \( D_{1} \) shifts the limiting point, achieving this goal. As shown in Fig. 3.49(b), the resulting circuit limits at \( V_{L}=V_{B 1}+V_{D, \text { on }} \). Note that \( V_{B 1} \) can be positive or negative to shift \( V_{L} \) to higher or lower values, respectively.

Second, the negative values of \( V_{i n} \) must also be limited. Starting with the circuit in Fig. 3.49(a), we recognize that reversing the anode and cathode of \( D_{1} \) causes the circuit to limit at \( V_{i n}=-V_{D, \text { on }} \) [Fig. 3.50(a)]. Therefore, as shown in Fig. 3.50(b), two "antiparallel" diodes can produce a characteristic that limits at \( \pm V_{D, o n} \). Finally, incorporating constant voltage sources in series with the diodes shifts the limiting points to arbitrary levels (Fig. 3.51).

Understanding doublers is facilitated by revisiting some fundamental properties of capacitors. Initially, to charge one plate of a capacitor to $+Q$, the opposing plate must be charged to $-Q$. Thus, in the circuit depicted in Fig. 3.54(a), the voltage across $C_{1}$ remains constant despite changes in $V_{i n}$, since the right plate of $C_{1}$ cannot acquire or release charge $(Q=C V)$. As $V_{C 1}$ stays constant, any input variation $\Delta V_{\text {in }}$ is directly reflected at the output. This is a crucial observation.

In addition, a capacitive voltage divider like that in Fig. 3.54(b) functions as follows. If $V_{i n}$ becomes more positive, the left plate of $C_{1}$ acquires positive charge from $V_{i n}$, necessitating that the right plate absorb an equivalent negative charge from the top plate of $C_{2}$. As the top plate of $C_{2}$ loses negative charge, it effectively gains more positive charge, causing the bottom plate to absorb negative charge from ground. It is important to note that all four plates experience an equal exchange of charge due to $C_{1}$ and $C_{2}$ being in series. To calculate the change in $V_{\text {out }}, \Delta V_{\text {out }}$, resulting from $\Delta V_{\text {in }}$, we express the change in charge on $C_{2}$ as $\Delta Q_{2}=C_{2} \cdot \Delta V_{\text {out }}$, which also applies to $C_{1}: \Delta Q_{2}=\Delta Q_{1}$. Therefore, the voltage change across $C_{1}$ equals $C_{2} \cdot \Delta V_{\text {out }} / C_{1}$. Summing these two voltage changes and equating the result to $\Delta V_{i n}$ yields

$$
\begin{equation*}
\Delta V_{\text {in }}=\frac{C_{2}}{C_{1}} \Delta V_{\text {out }}+\Delta V_{\text {out }} \tag{3.110}
\end{equation*}
$$

[^9]This simplifies to

$$
\begin{equation*}
\Delta V_{\text {out }}=\frac{C_{1}}{C_{1}+C_{2}} \Delta V_{\text {in }} \tag{3.111}
\end{equation*}
$$

This finding resembles the voltage division formula for resistive dividers, except that $C_{1}$ (instead of $C_{2}$) is in the numerator. Notably, the circuit of Fig. 3.54(a) is a special instance of the capacitive divider with $C_{2}=0$, leading to $\Delta V_{\text {out }}=\Delta V_{\text {in }}$.

Assuming an ideal diode and a zero initial condition across $C_{1}$, we observe that as $V_{\text {in }}$ exceeds zero, the input tends to place positive charge on the left plate of $C_{1}$ and hence draw negative charge from $D_{1}$. Consequently, $D_{1}$ turns on, forcing $V_{\text {out }}=0 .{ }^{18}$ As the input rises toward $V_{p}$, the voltage across $C_{1}$ remains equal to $V_{i n}$ because its right plate is "pinned" at zero by $D_{1}$. After $t=t_{1}$, $V_{\text {in }}$ begins to fall and tends to discharge $C_{1}$, i.e., draw positive charge from the left plate and hence from $D_{1}$. The diode therefore turns off, reducing the circuit to that in Fig. 3.54(a). From this time, the output simply tracks the changes in the input while $C_{1}$ sustains a constant voltage equal to $V_{p}$. In particular, as $V_{i n}$ varies from $+V_{p}$ to $-V_{p}$, the output goes from zero to $-2 V_{p}$, and the cycle repeats indefinitely.
